awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Shifting co-residence, sharing, and contact networks in a transitioning hunter-gatherer society
awd_abstract_narration:
The size and composition of human groups varies widely between societies, from the small bands of hunter-gatherers to the massive social networks of modern mega-cities. To understand the origins of this extreme variation, this doctoral dissertation project will study a small-scale society that is currently shifting from a life of nomadic hunting and gathering to one focused on sedentary agriculture. The co-PI will use innovative sensor technology to track the movements of individuals in order to reconstruct social networks and understand how those networks are related to demographics, food sharing, and residence patterns. This study is expected to shed light on the historical importance of living with close relatives and how the rise of agriculture has influenced human social interactions, especially the exchange of resources and information. Social networks also have major implications for health and the spread of disease, and this research aims to identify how the structure of social networks might mitigate disease susceptibility. This project will also provide student research and training opportunities for field and research assistants, and will include science communication and outreach activities at the home institution and the field site. 

Patterns of co-residence determine which individuals cooperate, compete, or share information and resources. This research will investigate the mechanisms that influence co-residence patterns and inter-individual interactions in a small-scale hunter-gatherer society, the Batek of Malaysia, for whom cooperation is critical for survival. The co-PI will collect detailed demographic, co-residence, and food sharing data in permanent settlements and forest camps, and analyze these data in conjunction with a rich historical dataset collected in the mid-1970s on the same population. In addition, the project will include the use of sensor technology to monitor proximity interactions among individuals and reconstruct social networks. Given the increasing sedentarization of the Batek, coupled with a shift towards male-dominated gender relations, specific predictions include (i) an increase in relatedness among co-residents, (ii) an increase in kin-biased and reciprocal sharing interactions, and (iii) broader but less evenly distributed contact networks. This project builds on a recent synthesis of research on human co-residence patterns, and provides the first empirical test of a new theoretical model proposed to explain these patterns. Findings from this project will provide an important baseline for evaluating the effect of sedentarization on fundamental human interaction patterns and how human social organization mediates the spread of information and disease.

por.por_cntn:
We humans are compelled to live in groups, yet the size and composition of groups varies widely between societies, from the small bands of hunter-gatherers to the massive social networks of modern mega-cities. To understand the origins of this extreme variation, this project investigated residence patterns and interaction patterns in a small-scale society (the Batek of Malaysia) that is presently shifting from a life of nomadic hunting and gathering to one focused on sedentary agriculture and other economic pursuits.

We found that, like many other hunter-gatherer populations, the Batek have a very different social organization than many other contemporary societies. Specifically, people live in small groups with many close kin, and adult brothers and sisters often live in the same groups. People were not necessarily as closely related as expected, however, as over 50% of group members were found to be unrelated. Although previous research has suggested that gender equality in decision-making leads to the formation of groups with a surprising number of unrelated individuals, our data show no evidence of this being the case. Instead, relatedness may be primarily determined by other factors, such as how many individuals live in a group. Finally, we found that Batek living in settlements have remarkably similar social structures to forest living groups in the past. 

Our research also employed a novel sensor technology to track the social interactions of Batek individuals. Using miniature sensors developed by collaborators at University College London, we asked ~140 study participants to wear armbands containing these tiny devices in order to track contacts between individuals. The sensors capture close range interactions at high-resolution, and have allowed us to characterize social networks in detail over time.

Analysis of these social networks demonstrates the extreme level of connectivity that exists in a small-scale hunter-gatherer society -- nearly all camp members interact on a daily basis either directly, or indirectly via one or two other individuals. These patterns appear to be changing, however, as the Batek move out of small rainforest camps and increasingly into government settlements. In these settlements, which are much larger than rainforest camps, contact networks are clustered into local groups, with specific people acting as links between those groups. Important changes in interactions between men and women are also occurring. Given that contact between people is a fundamental part of transmission, social network data such as these have major implications for health and the spread of disease, and this research aims to identify how the structure of social networks might mitigate disease susceptibility.

Modified by: Thomas Kraft
